Whilst this is the consensus viewpoint amongst the majority of academics
column2: some teachers and parents advocate a more assertive and confrontational style of discipline.[citation needed] Such individuals claim that many problems with modern schooling stem from the   weakness in school discipline   and if teachers exercised firm control over the classroom they would be able to teach more efficiently. This viewpoint is supported by the educational attainment of countries—in East Asia for instance—that combine strict discipline with high standards of education.[citation needed] ### Answer: weakness in school discipline  - What do critics think the cause of problems with modern schooling is? - weakness in school discipline

column1: Perhaps the most significant difference between primary school and secondary school teaching is   the relationship between teachers and children  . In primary schools each class has a teacher who stays with them for most of the week and will teach them the whole curriculum. In secondary schools they will be taught by different subject specialists each session during the week and may have ten or more different teachers. The relationship between children and their teachers tends to be closer in the primary school where they act as form tutor
column2: specialist teacher and surrogate parent during the course of the day. ### Answer: the relationship between teachers and children  - What's the biggest difference in the teaching relationship for primary and secondary school? - the relationship between teachers and children

column1: Before the actual research explicitly devoted to the complexity of algorithmic problems started off
column2: numerous foundations were laid out by various researchers. Most influential among these was the definition of Turing machines by   Alan Turing   in 1936
column3: which turned out to be a very robust and flexible simplification of a computer. ### Answer: Alan Turing  - Who was the most influential researcher among those grappling with the deficit of work surrounding the complexity posed by algorithmic problems? - Alan Turing

column1: What intractability means in practice is open to debate. Saying that a problem is not in P does not imply that all large cases of the problem are hard or even that most of them are. For example
column2: the decision problem in Presburger arithmetic has been shown not to be in P
column3: yet algorithms have been written that solve the problem in reasonable times in most cases. Similarly
column4: algorithms can solve the NP-complete knapsack problem over a wide range of sizes   in less than quadratic time   and SAT solvers routinely handle large instances of the NP-complete Boolean satisfiability problem. ### Answer: in less than quadratic time  - How quickly can an algorithm solve an NP-complete knapsack problem? - in less than quadratic time

column1: In December 1878
column2: Tesla left Graz and severed all relations with his family to hide the fact that he dropped out of school. His friends thought that he had drowned in the Mur River. Tesla went to Maribor (now in Slovenia)
column3: where he worked as   a draftsman   for 60 florins a month. He spent his spare time playing cards with local men on the streets. In March 1879
column4: Milutin Tesla went to Maribor to beg his son to return home
column5: but Nikola refused. Nikola suffered a nervous breakdown at around the same time. ### Answer: a draftsman  - What did Tesla work as after dropping out?  - a draftsman

column1: This motivates the concept of a problem being hard for a complexity class. A problem X is hard for a class of problems C   if every problem in C can be reduced to X  . Thus no problem in C is harder than X
column2: since an algorithm for X allows us to solve any problem in C. Of course
column3: the notion of hard problems depends on the type of reduction being used. For complexity classes larger than P
column4: polynomial-time reductions are commonly used. In particular
column5: the set of problems that are hard for NP is the set of NP-hard problems. ### Answer: if every problem in C can be reduced to X  - What would create a conflict between a problem X and problem C within the context of reduction?  - if every problem in C can be reduced to X

column1: Tesla could be harsh at times and openly expressed disgust for overweight people
column2: such as when he fired a   secretary   because of her weight.:110 He was quick to criticize clothing; on several occasions
column3: Tesla directed a subordinate to go home and change her dress.:33 ### Answer: secretary  - Who did he fire? - secretary

column1: A modern example of school discipline in North America and Western Europe relies upon the idea of an assertive teacher who is prepared to impose their will upon a class. Positive reinforcement is balanced with   immediate and fair punishment for misbehavior   and firm
column2: clear boundaries define what is appropriate and inappropriate behavior. Teachers are expected to respect their students; sarcasm and attempts to humiliate pupils are seen as falling outside of what constitutes reasonable discipline.[verification needed] ### Answer: immediate and fair punishment for misbehavior  - What is the balance for positive reinforcement? - immediate and fair punishment for misbehavior

column2: with dinner from exactly   8:10 p.m  .
column3: at Delmonico's restaurant and later the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. Tesla would telephone his dinner order to the headwaiter
column4: who also could be the only one to serve him. "The meal was required to be ready at eight o'clock ... He dined alone
column5: except on the rare occasions when he would give a dinner to a group to meet his social obligations. Tesla would then resume his work
column6: often until 3:00 a.m.":283
column7: 286 ### Answer: 8:10 p.m  - At what time did Tesla get dinner? - 8:10 p.m

column1: Since teachers can affect how students perceive the course materials
column2: it has been found that teachers who showed   enthusiasm   towards the course materials and students can affect a positive learning experience towards the course materials. On teacher/course evaluations
column3: it was found that teachers who have a positive disposition towards the course content tend to transfer their passion to receptive students. These teachers do not teach by rote but attempt to find new invigoration for the course materials on a daily basis. One of the difficulties in this approach is that teachers may have repeatedly covered a curriculum until they begin to feel bored with the subject which in turn bores the students as well. Students who had enthusiastic teachers tend to rate them higher than teachers who didn't show much enthusiasm for the course materials. ### Answer: enthusiasm  - What must a teacher show towards the course materials for increase learning? - enthusiasm

column2: Tesla moved to   Budapest   to work under Ferenc Puskás at a telegraph company

column5: then under construction

column10: which was never patented nor publicly described. ### Answer: Budapest  - Where did Tesla move in 1881? - Budapest

column1: Later in life
column2: Tesla made claims concerning a "teleforce" weapon after studying the Van de Graaff generator. The press variably referred to it as a "peace ray" or death ray. column1: On 17 May 1899
column2: Tesla moved to Colorado Springs
column3: where he would have room for his high-voltage
column4: high-frequency experiments; his lab was located near Foote Ave. and Kiowa St. He chose this location because the polyphase alternating current power distribution system had been introduced there and he had associates who were willing to give him all the power he needed without charging for it. Upon his arrival
column5: he told reporters that he was conducting wireless telegraphy experiments
column6: transmitting signals from Pikes Peak to Paris.[citation needed] The 1978 book Colorado Springs Notes
column7: 1899–1900 contains descriptions of Tesla's experiments. On   15 June 1899
column8: Tesla performed his first experiments at his Colorado Springs lab; he recorded his initial spark length at five inches long
column9: but very thick and noisy. ### Answer: 15 June 1899  - What date did Tesla begin his Colorado Springs experiments? - 15 June 1899

column1: Warsaw (Polish: Warszawa [varˈʂava] ( listen); see also other names) is the capital and largest city of Poland. It stands on the Vistula River in east-central Poland
column2: roughly 260 kilometres (160 mi) from the Baltic Sea and 300 kilometres (190 mi) from the Carpathian Mountains. Its population is estimated at 1.740 million residents within a greater metropolitan area of   2.666 million   residents
column3: which makes Warsaw the 9th most-populous capital city in the European Union. The city limits cover 516.9 square kilometres (199.6 sq mi)
column4: while the metropolitan area covers 6
column5: 100.43 square kilometres (2
column6: 355.39 sq mi). ### Answer: 2.666 million  - How many residents does the greater metropolitan area have? - 2.666 million

column1: The Normans (Norman: Nourmands; French: Normands; Latin: Normanni) were the people who in the 10th and 11th centuries gave their name to Normandy
column2: a region in France. They were descended from Norse ("Norman" comes from "Norseman") raiders and pirates from Denmark
column3: Iceland and Norway who
column4: under their leader Rollo
column5: agreed to swear fealty to King Charles III of West Francia. Through generations of assimilation and mixing with the native Frankish and Roman-Gaulish populations
column6: their descendants would gradually merge with the Carolingian-based cultures of West Francia. The distinct cultural and ethnic identity of the Normans emerged initially in the first half of the   10th century
column7: and it continued to evolve over the succeeding centuries. ### Answer: 10th century  - What century did the Normans first gain their separate identity? - 10th century

column1: Many known complexity classes are suspected to be unequal
column2: but this has not been proved. For instance P ⊆ NP ⊆ PP ⊆ PSPACE
column3: but it is possible that P = PSPACE. If P is not equal to NP
column4: then P is not equal to PSPACE either. Since there are many known complexity classes   between P and PSPACE
column5: such as RP
column6: BPP
column7: PP
column8: BQP
column12: it is possible that all these complexity classes collapse to one class. Proving that any of these classes are unequal would be a major breakthrough in complexity theory. ### Answer: between P and PSPACE  - Where can the complexity classes RP
column17: and PH be located? - between P and PSPACE

column1: Starting in 1894
column2: Tesla began investigating what he referred to as radiant energy of "invisible" kinds after he had noticed damaged film in his laboratory in previous experiments (later identified as "Roentgen rays" or "X-Rays"). His early experiments were with Crookes tubes
column3: a cold cathode electrical discharge tube. Soon after
column4: much of Tesla's early research—hundreds of invention models
column5: plans
column6: notes
column7: laboratory data
column8: tools
column11: 000—was lost in the 5th Avenue laboratory fire of March 1895. Tesla is quoted by The New York Times as saying
column12: "I am in too much grief to talk. What can I say?" Tesla may have inadvertently captured an X-ray image—predating
column14: Wilhelm Röntgen's December 1895 announcement of the discovery of x-rays—when he tried to photograph   Mark Twain   illuminated by a Geissler tube
column15: an earlier type of gas discharge tube. The only thing captured in the image was the metal locking screw on the camera lens.:134 ### Answer: Mark Twain  - Who was Tesla trying to photograph when he accidentally took the X-Ray image? - Mark Twain

column1: Institutionally
column2: the Normans combined the administrative machinery of the Byzantines
column3: Arabs
column4: and Lombards with their own conceptions of feudal law and order to forge a unique government. Under this state
column5: there was great religious freedom
column6: and alongside the Norman nobles existed a meritocratic bureaucracy of Jews
column7: Muslims and Christians
column8: both Catholic and Eastern Orthodox. The Kingdom of Sicily thus became characterized by Norman
column11: Lombard and "native" Sicilian populations living in harmony
column12: and its Norman rulers fostered plans of establishing an Empire that would have encompassed Fatimid Egypt as well as the Crusader states in the Levant. One of the great geographical treatises of the Middle Ages
column14: was written by the Andalusian al-Idrisi for king Roger II of Sicily
column15: and entitled "  Kitab Rudjdjar  " ("The Book of Roger"). ### Answer: Kitab Rudjdjar  - What is another name for the Tabula Rogeriana? - Kitab Rudjdjar

column1: Other important complexity classes include BPP
column2: ZPP and RP
column3: which are defined using probabilistic Turing machines; AC and NC
column4: which are defined using   Boolean   circuits; and BQP and QMA
column5: which are defined using quantum Turing machines. #P is an important complexity class of counting problems (not decision problems). Classes like IP and AM are defined using Interactive proof systems. ALL is the class of all decision problems. ### Answer: Boolean  - AC and NC are complexity classes typically associated with what type of circuit? - Boolean

column1: For a precise definition of what it means to solve a problem using a given amount of   time   and space
column2: a computational model such as the deterministic Turing machine is used. The time required by a deterministic Turing machine M on input x is the total number of state transitions
column3: or steps
column4: the machine makes before it halts and outputs the answer ("yes" or "no"). A Turing machine M is said to operate within time f(n)
column5: if the time required by M on each input of length n is at most f(n). A decision problem A can be solved in time f(n) if there exists a Turing machine operating in time f(n) that solves the problem. Since complexity theory is interested in classifying problems based on their difficulty
column6: one defines sets of problems based on some criteria. For instance
column7: the set of problems solvable within time f(n) on a deterministic Turing machine is then denoted by DTIME(f(n)). ### Answer: time  - What is the most critical resource measured to in assessing the determination of a Turing machine's ability to solve any given set of problems? - time

column1: The flora of the city may be considered very rich in species. The species richness is mainly due to the location of Warsaw within the border region of several big floral regions comprising substantial proportions of close-to-wilderness areas (natural forests
column2: wetlands along the Vistula) as well as arable land
column3: meadows and forests. Bielany Forest
column4: located within the borders of Warsaw
column5: is the remaining part of the Masovian Primeval Forest. Bielany Forest nature reserve is connected with Kampinos Forest. It is home to rich fauna and flora. Within the forest there are three cycling and walking trails. Other big forest area is   Kabaty   Forest by the southern city border. Warsaw has also two botanic gardens: by the Łazienki park (a didactic-research unit of the University of Warsaw) as well as by the Park of Culture and Rest in Powsin (a unit of the Polish Academy of Science). ### Answer: Kabaty  - What forest is by Warsaw's southern border? - Kabaty

column1: Co-teaching has also become a new trend amongst educational institutions. Co-teaching is defined as two or more teachers working harmoniously to fulfill the needs of every student in the classroom. Co-teaching focuses the student on   learning   by providing a social networking support that allows them to reach their full cognitive potential. Co-teachers work in sync with one another to create a climate of learning. ### Answer: learning  - What does co-teaching get the students to focus on? - learning
Upper and lower bounds are usually stated using the big O notation
column2: which hides constant factors and smaller terms. This makes the bounds independent of the specific details of the computational model used. For instance

column1: This is true throughout most of the United States as well. However
column2: alternative approaches for primary education do exist. One of these
column3: sometimes referred to as a "platoon" system
column4: involves placing a group of students together in one class that moves from one specialist to another for every subject. The advantage here is that students learn from teachers who specialize in one subject and who tend to be more   knowledgeable   in that one area than a teacher who teaches many subjects. Students still derive a strong sense of security by staying with the same group of peers for all classes. ### Answer: knowledgeable  - The teacher's in a platoon style teaching are usually more _____? - knowledgeable

column1: Legislative power in Warsaw is vested in a unicameral Warsaw City Council (Rada Miasta)
column2: which comprises 60 members. Council members are elected directly every four years. Like most legislative bodies
column3: the City Council divides itself into   committees   which have the oversight of various functions of the city government. Bills passed by a simple majority are sent to the mayor (the President of Warsaw)
column4: who may sign them into law. If the mayor vetoes a bill
column5: the Council has 30 days to override the veto by a two-thirds majority vote. ### Answer: committees  - What does the City Council divide itself into? - committees

Nikola Tesla (Serbian Cyrillic: Никола Тесла; 10 July 1856 – 7 January   1943  ) was a Serbian American inventor, electrical engineer, mechanical engineer, physicist, and futurist best known for his contributions to the design of the modern alternating current (AC) electricity supply system. ### Answer: 1943  - In what year did Tesla die?  - 1943
On 30 July 1891, at the age of 35, Tesla became a naturalized citizen of the United States, and established his South Fifth Avenue laboratory, and later another at 46 E. Houston Street, in New York. He lit electric lamps wirelessly at both locations, demonstrating the potential of wireless power transmission. In the same year, he patented   the Tesla coil.   ### Answer: the Tesla coil.  - What did Tesla patent in 1891? - the Tesla coil.
Sudbury model democratic schools claim that popularly based authority can maintain order more effectively than dictatorial authority for governments and schools alike. They also claim that in these schools the preservation of public order is easier and more efficient than anywhere else. Primarily because rules and regulations are made by the community as a whole, thence the school atmosphere is one of persuasion and negotiation, rather than confrontation since there is no one to confront. Sudbury model democratic schools' proponents argue that a school that has   good, clear laws  , fairly and democratically passed by the entire school community, and a good judicial system for enforcing these laws, is a school in which community discipline prevails, and in which an increasingly sophisticated concept of law and order develops, against other schools today, where rules are arbitrary, authority is absolute, punishment is capricious, and due process of law is unknown. ### Answer: good, clear laws  - What must be passed using democratic means by the entire school community? - good, clear laws
Tesla obtained around 300 patents worldwide for his inventions. Some of Tesla's patents are not accounted for, and various sources have discovered some that have lain hidden in   patent archives  . There are a minimum of 278 patents issued to Tesla in 26 countries that have been accounted for. Many of Tesla's patents were in the United States, Britain, and Canada, but many other patents were approved in countries around the globe.:62 Many inventions developed by Tesla were not put into patent protection. ### Answer: patent archives  -  Where were missing patents later found? - patent archives
When considering computational problems, a problem instance is a string over an alphabet. Usually, the alphabet is taken to be the   binary alphabet   (i.e., the set {0,1}), and thus the strings are bitstrings. As in a real-world computer, mathematical objects other than bitstrings must be suitably encoded. For example, integers can be represented in binary notation, and graphs can be encoded directly via their adjacency matrices, or by encoding their adjacency lists in binary. ### Answer: binary alphabet  - What is the name of the alphabet is most commonly used in a problem instance? - binary alphabet
In   March 1896  , after hearing of Wilhelm Röntgen's discovery of X-ray and X-ray imaging (radiography), Tesla proceeded to do his own experiments in X-ray imaging, developing a high energy single terminal vacuum tube of his own design that had no target electrode and that worked from the output of the Tesla Coil (the modern term for the phenomenon produced by this device is bremsstrahlung or braking radiation). In his research, Tesla devised several experimental setups to produce X-rays. Tesla held that, with his circuits, the instrument will ... enable one to generate Roentgen rays of much greater power than obtainable with ordinary apparatus." ### Answer: March 1896  - when did tesla begin researching x-ray imaging? - March 1896

column1: The most commonly used reduction is a polynomial-time reduction. This means that the reduction process takes   polynomial time  . For example
column2: the problem of squaring an integer can be reduced to the problem of multiplying two integers. This means an algorithm for multiplying two integers can be used to square an integer. Indeed
column3: this can be done by giving the same input to both inputs of the multiplication algorithm. Thus we see that squaring is not more difficult than multiplication
column4: since squaring can be reduced to multiplication. ### Answer: polynomial time  - What measurement of time is used in polynomial time reduction? - polynomial time

column1: One of the things Tesla developed at that laboratory in 1887 was an induction motor that ran on alternating current
column2: a power system format that was starting to be built in Europe and the United States because of its advantages in long-distance
column3: high-voltage transmission. The motor used polyphase current which generated a rotating magnetic field to turn the motor (a principle Tesla claimed to have conceived in 1882). This innovative electric motor
column4: patented in May 1888
column5: was a simple self-starting design that did not need a commutator
column6: thus avoiding sparking and the high maintenance of constantly servicing and replacing   mechanical brushes  . ### Answer: mechanical brushes  - What high maintenance part did Tesla's AC motor not require? - mechanical brushes

column1: Decision problems are one of the central objects of study in computational complexity theory. A decision problem is a special type of computational problem whose answer is either   yes   or no
column2: or alternately either 1 or 0. A decision problem can be viewed as a formal language
column3: where the members of the language are instances whose output is yes
column4: and the non-members are those instances whose output is no. The objective is to decide
column5: with the aid of an algorithm
column6: whether a given input string is a member of the formal language under consideration. If the algorithm deciding this problem returns the answer yes
column7: the algorithm is said to accept the input string
column8: otherwise it is said to reject the input. ### Answer: yes  - What will the output be for a member of the language of a decision problem? - yes

column1: What intractability means in practice is open to debate. Saying that a problem is not in P does not imply that all large cases of the problem are hard or even that most of them are. For example
column2: the decision problem in Presburger arithmetic has been shown not to be in P
column3: yet algorithms have been written that solve the problem in reasonable times in most cases. Similarly
column4: algorithms can solve the NP-complete knapsack problem over a wide range of sizes in less than quadratic time and SAT solvers routinely handle large instances of the   NP-complete Boolean satisfiability problem  . ### Answer: NP-complete Boolean satisfiability problem  - What is the example of another problem characterized by large instances that is routinely solved by SAT handlers employing efficient algorithms? - NP-complete Boolean satisfiability problem

column1: But bounding the computation time above by some concrete function f(n) often yields complexity classes that depend on the chosen machine model. For instance
column2: the language {xx | x is any binary string} can be solved in linear time on a multi-tape Turing machine
column3: but necessarily requires quadratic time in the model of single-tape Turing machines. If we allow polynomial variations in running time
column4: Cobham-Edmonds thesis   states that "the time complexities in any two reasonable and general models of computation are polynomially related" (Goldreich 2008
column5: Chapter 1.2). This forms the basis for the complexity class P
column6: which is the set of decision problems solvable by a deterministic Turing machine within polynomial time. The corresponding set of function problems is FP. ### Answer: Cobham-Edmonds thesis  - What thesis specifies that a polynomial relationship exists within time complexities in a computational model?  - Cobham-Edmonds thesis

column5: Richard's fleet arrived in the port of Limassol on Cyprus. He ordered Isaac to release the prisoners and the treasure. Isaac refused
column6: so Richard landed his troops and took Limassol. ### Answer: 1191  - What year did the storm hit Richard's fleet? - 1191

column1: Teaching using pedagogy also involve assessing the educational levels of the students on particular skills. Understanding the pedagogy of the students in a classroom involves using differentiated instruction as well as supervision to meet the needs of all students in the classroom. Pedagogy can be thought of in two manners. First
column2: teaching itself can be taught in many different ways
column3: hence
column4: using a pedagogy of teaching styles. Second
column5: the pedagogy of the learners comes into play when a teacher assesses the pedagogic diversity of his/her students and differentiates for the individual students accordingly. For example
column6: an experienced teacher and parent described the place of a teacher in learning as follows: "The real bulk of learning takes place in self-study and problem solving with a lot of feedback around that loop. The function of the teacher is to pressure the lazy
column7: inspire the bored
column8: deflate   the cocky
column11: and broaden the viewpoint of all. This function looks like that of a coach using the whole gamut of psychology to get each new class of rookies off the bench and into the game." ### Answer: deflate  - What would a teacher do for someone who is cocky? - deflate

Since teachers can affect how students perceive the course materials, it has been found that teachers who showed enthusiasm towards the course materials and students can affect a positive learning experience towards the course materials. On teacher/course evaluations, it was found that teachers who have a positive disposition towards the course content tend to transfer their   passion   to receptive students. These teachers do not teach by rote but attempt to find new invigoration for the course materials on a daily basis. One of the difficulties in this approach is that teachers may have repeatedly covered a curriculum until they begin to feel bored with the subject which in turn bores the students as well. Students who had enthusiastic teachers tend to rate them higher than teachers who didn't show much enthusiasm for the course materials. ### Answer: passion  - What gets transferred to students who are receptive to the teacher? - passion
Warsaw, especially its city centre (Śródmieście), is home not only to many national institutions and government agencies, but also to many domestic and international companies. In 2006, 304,016 companies were registered in the city. Warsaw's ever-growing business community has been noticed globally, regionally, and nationally. MasterCard Emerging Market Index has noted Warsaw's economic strength and commercial center. Moreover, Warsaw was ranked as the 7th greatest emerging market. Foreign investors' financial participation in the city's development was estimated in 2002 at over 650 million euro. Warsaw produces 12% of Poland's national income, which in 2008 was 305.1% of the Polish average, per capita (or 160% of the European Union average). The GDP per capita in Warsaw amounted to PLN 94 000 in 2008 (c. EUR 23 800, USD 33 000). Total nominal GDP of the city in 2010 amounted to   191.766 billion PLN  , 111696 PLN per capita, which was 301,1 % of Polish average. Warsaw leads the region of East-Central Europe in foreign investment and in 2006, GDP growth met expectations with a level of 6.1%. It also has one of the fastest growing economies, with GDP growth at 6.5 percent in 2007 and 6.1 percent in the first quarter of 2008. ### Answer: 191.766 billion PLN  - What was the total nominal GDP of Warsaw in 2010? - 191.766 billion PLN
In 1935, in an annual birthday celebration interview, Tesla announced a method of transmitting mechanical energy with minimal loss over any terrestrial distance, a related new means of communication, and a method of accurately determining the location of underground   mineral deposits  . ### Answer: mineral deposits  - What did he hope to locate underground? - mineral deposits
The Normans had a profound effect on   Irish   culture and history after their invasion at Bannow Bay in 1169. Initially the Normans maintained a distinct culture and ethnicity. Yet, with time, they came to be subsumed into Irish culture to the point that it has been said that they became more Irish than the Irish themselves." The Normans settled mostly in an area in the east of Ireland
column4: later known as the Pale
column5: and also built many fine castles and settlements
column6: including Trim Castle and Dublin Castle. Both cultures intermixed
column7: borrowing from each other's language
column8: culture and outlook. Norman descendants today can be recognised by their surnames. Names such as French
column12: Treacy and Lacy are particularly common in the southeast of Ireland
column13: especially in the southern part of County Wexford where the first Norman settlements were established. Other Norman names such as Furlong predominate there. Another common Norman-Irish name was Morell (Murrell) derived from the French Norman name Morel. Other names beginning with Fitz (from the Norman for son) indicate Norman ancestry. These included Fitzgerald
column15: Fitzmaurice. Other families bearing such surnames as Barry (de Barra) and De Búrca (Burke) are also of Norman extraction. ### Answer: Irish  - What culture did the Normans combine with in Ireland? - Irish

column1: Tesla noted the hazards of working with his circuit and single-node X-ray-producing devices. In his many notes on the early investigation of this phenomenon
column2: he attributed the skin damage to various causes. He believed early on that damage to the skin was not caused by the Roentgen rays
column3: but by the ozone generated in contact with the skin
column4: and to a lesser extent
column5: by nitrous acid. Tesla incorrectly believed that   X-rays were longitudinal waves
column6: such as those produced in waves in plasmas. These plasma waves can occur in force-free magnetic fields. ### Answer: X-rays were longitudinal waves  - What did tesla incorrectly believe about x-rays? - X-rays were longitudinal waves

column1: In 1893 Richard Dean Adams
column2: who headed up the Niagara Falls Cataract Construction Company sought Tesla's opinion on what system would be best to transmit power generated at the falls. Over several years there had been a series of proposals and open competitions on how best to utilize power generated by the falls with many systems being proposed by several US and European companies including two-phase and three-phase AC
column3: high-voltage DC
column4: and even compressed air. Adams pumped Tesla for information about the current state of all the competing systems. Tesla advised Adams that a two-phased system would be the most reliable and that there was a Westinghouse system to light incandescent bulbs using two-phase alternating current. Based on Tesla's advice and Westinghouse's demonstration that they could build a complete AC system at the Columbian Exposition
column5: a contract for building a two-phase AC generating system at the Niagara Falls was awarded to Westinghouse Electric. A further contract to build the AC distribution system was awarded to   General Electric  . ### Answer: General Electric  - What company was chosen to build an AC distribution system at Niagara Falls? - General Electric

column1: For a precise definition of what it means to solve a problem using a given amount of time and space
column2: a computational model such as the deterministic Turing machine is used. The time required by a deterministic Turing machine M on input x is the total number of state transitions
column3: or steps
column4: the machine makes before it halts and outputs the answer ("yes" or "no"). A Turing machine M is said to operate within time f(n)
column5: if the time required by M on each input of length n is at most f(n). A decision problem A can be solved in time f(n) if there exists a Turing machine operating in time f(n) that solves the problem. Since complexity theory is interested in classifying problems based on their   difficulty
column6: one defines sets of problems based on some criteria. For instance
column7: the set of problems solvable within time f(n) on a deterministic Turing machine is then denoted by DTIME(f(n)). ### Answer: difficulty  - Complexity theory classifies problems based on what primary attribute? - difficulty
